posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked:
Over the last few days, I’ve had to program an auto-positioning, but when I press the auto-positioning button, the Swerve goes into X position and doesn’t move forward. As such, it’s not an error that appears on the driver station. I honestly don’t know what it is. I’m starting to think it’s a drive-to-pose error, because I’ve printed the odometry data to the smart dashboard and everything seems to be correct. I’ve asked the programmer on my team and on another team, but they have no idea why the swerve goes into position X. I’m going to leave a video showing the problem and what I mean, as well as the GitHub link to my code in case anyone can help me figure out what’s going on and why my swerve goes to X and doesn’t move forward.

The swerve goes into position X when I press the auto-position button. If I don’t press it, the swerve continues to move quite well, and even if I press the auto-position button, the swerve can still move.

video link

link to my code

GitHub - bcarrillocampillo-code/OffSeason Contribute to bcarrillocampillo-code/OffSeason development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to bcarrillocampillo-code/OffSeason development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Does it do the same thing in sim? (This is a easy way to make sure its not an encoder or mechanical issue)

One thing to double check is where the robot thinks it is when you press the drive-to-pose button. If you are somewhere accidentally setting the current pose to the target pose, that might explain why the robot is going into the X formation, because it thinks it just needs to lock in it’s current position.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: The truth is, I don’t have any simulator installed, nor do I know how to use it (yet) to check whether the code works or not. All I know is that when I asked another programmer from another team, he said that we used the same thing for auto-alignment, the path planner, but he didn’t know why it was set to x for me.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: I’ve been checking that with SmartDashboard, making it print its current position and the position of its destination, but as far as I can see, it’s fine.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Yagsl comes with a simulator built in. All you should need to do is click simulate robot code instead of deploy robot code and it should open up.

posts.name: Owen Flanagan
posts.cooked: Also for future reference the YAGSL discord is a great resource to ask questions. Chief Delphi also totally works but the discord has extra amazing support.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: I already checked that self-positioning thing, but nothing happens in the YAGSL simulator. I don’t know if it’s because my code needs to get the ID from the Limelight April tag and the simulator can’t do that, or I don’t know what’s going on. But thanks for your advice. I’ll post it there too.

I am pretty sure your issue is this.

Or you zero’d your absolute encoders with the bevels facing wherever instead of of all to the left.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: I checked the link you sent me, but from what I can see, everything is configured correctly, it’s done right, and position 0 is to the left (that’s what I was taught first). The thing is, the swerve moves on its own, it works when you drive it, but when I press the auto-position button, it goes to position X.
Can you spin in place?

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: Yes, if I drive the robot, I can turn it around in the same spot.

Can you send a video of what happens in sim?

You are definitely right that my first suspicion was incorrect if you can spin in place.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: Here is the video. You can see that everything works fine with the robot’s controls, but when you click on the button that is supposed to jump to the position using the drive to pose method, the swerve goes to position X. I’m uploading it to YouTube because I don’t know how to upload a video here, or even if it’s possible. Or maybe you were referring to the simulator that comes with your library?
I was talking about that simulator. It will reveal if its a misconfig or a command issue

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: Ahhhhh, okay, sorry. I’ll send you a video right now. I’m trying to figure out how to use the simulator. I tried to test it, but I don’t know if the fact that my code uses Limelight to get the ID from the April tag affects it. I don’t know if that affects the simulator because I tried to use it and it only marked the robot’s X and Y position on the field. Does Limelight affect it?

Maybe. You can just comment it out and set the starting Pose.

Have you seen the simulator video from YouTube?

It should be a good starting point. We’re releasing more videos tomorrow hopefully!

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: Ohhhhhh okay, I’ll try it right now. The truth is, I’m pretty new to this and I’ve been struggling. I apologize if there are things I don’t know well, but thank you very much, nstrike. I’ll try it right now.
No problem! Swerve drives are difficult and drive to pose is even more difficult!

posts.cooked: could be wrong, but is leftBumper not double binded?:
